'Twas at a feast, triumphant in the blow</br>Aim'd basely at Moreau:</br>In insolence elate</br>The sullen Consul sate</br>With Oriental shew:</br>His swarthy Mamelukes were plac'd around;</br>Their loins with keen Damascus sabres bound:</br>(No Frenchman near his person found).</br>His barren dame, dispelling spleen</br>By luxury's vain-glorious scene,</br>Sate by his side a painted quean.</br>Happy, happy, happy party!</br>Barras would ne'er</br>His mistress spare</br>But to a friend like Bonaparte.

Denon, amidst the croud,</br>With subtle servile tongue,</br>His birth and famous exploits sung:</br>And rais'd the panegyric loud,</br>Till all the palace rung.</br>From Moloch rose the tale,</br>Who left dire Hinnom's distant vale,</br>'Midst infant shrieks, and mothers' wail;</br>Stern Attila's dread form the demon took:</br>O'er Bastia's tow'rs his wings he shook,</br>Then darting down, his hand he press'd</br>On Salicetti's wanton breast;</br>Around her prostituted frame entwin'd,</br>And stamp'd an image of the Hun, a scourge of all mankind.</br>The throng adore the monstrous progeny,</br>The Scourge of God!  the nations round reply.</br>Proud of the worth</br>Of such a birth,</br>He grasps the sword,</br>He gives the word</br>Of havoc through the earth.

The praise of Talleyrand, the fawning flatt'rer told;</br>Of Talleyrand in knavish cunning old;</br>See the apostate Bishop comes;</br>Diplomatics!  bite your thumbs.</br>Devoid of honest grace,</br>He shews his Jesuit face,</br>To take the envoy's bribe he smirking comes.</br>Talleyrand so mean and sly,</br>Bribes delighteth to retain;</br>America's possess'd of treasure,</br>Stealing is the Frenchman's pleasure;</br>Rich the treasure,</br>Sweet the pleasure;</br>Sweet the bribe of Louisiane.

Marking the deed with spiteful smile,</br>The Consul prais'd his villain's guile;</br>Resolv'd to seize the prey like European spoil.</br>The parasite with anxious eyes</br>Saw avaricious madness rise;</br>And, startled at his frantic frown,</br>Chose a theme to bring him down.</br>For e'en his hireling Muse</br>A dirge could not refuse</br>To youthful Bourbon, great and good,</br>By Rancour's lawless hate,</br>Hurried, hurried, hurried, hurried,</br>Hurried from his peaceful gate.—</br>Glory of Conde's blood,</br>Doom'd to insult's bitter pains,</br>Manacled with galling chains;</br>Ah!  see he falls, embalm'd he dies,</br>With patriot tears, with Europe's sighs.</br>With gloomy looks the sallow tyrant sate,</br>Remorse had seiz'd his vengeful soul,</br>Foreboding thoughts his mind engage;</br>And from his lips some curses stole</br>Upon his headstrong rage.

Discordant passions urg'd too far,</br>Thus stirring up intestine war;</br>His slave to rouse ambition strove,</br>The pangs of conscience to remove.</br>With hope of an imperial toy,</br>Soon he wakens selfish joy.</br>War with Britain was but trouble;</br>Invasion a mere empty bubble;</br>Badly ending, long beginning,</br>Building those, and they destroying;</br>If this realm was worth thy winning,</br>Think its crown is worth enjoying:</br>See the prize now plac'd beside thee,</br>Take the crown the Gauls provide thee.</br>Thy Janizaries shall ensure applause;</br>And forc'd addresses aid the glorious cause.</br>The Corsican, so arrogant and vain,</br>Gaz'd on the crown,</br>And then look'd down,</br>And thought and gaz'd, thought and gaz'd,</br>Thought and gaz'd, and thought again:</br>Eager at length the diadem to wrest,</br>He felt an air-drawn dagger at his breast.

Now Adulation's voice again</br>Had pour'd some fascinating strain;</br>When spectres fill'd the hall with wonder,</br>And rous'd the hero like Sir Sidney's thunder.</br>Hark, hark, at the sound</br>How he casts down his head;</br>For with menaces dread</br>Pale phantoms stalk around.</br>Revenge, revenge, fierce Toussaint cries,</br>See brave Kleber arise,</br>By his order who bled,</br>When from Egypt he fled,</br>And his army forsook in disguise.</br>Behold a ghastly band,</br>Each a bowl in his hand!</br>Those are Gallic ghosts that by poison were slain,</br>And at Jaffa remain</br>Unburied on the plain.</br>Give the vengeance due</br>To the Turkish crew,</br>Behold how they point to the massacred dead,</br>And call down horrors on the murd'rer's head.—</br>From his palace the despot thus forc'd to retreat,</br>Embark'd in a fury stout Britons to beat;</br>Folly led the way,</br>As though they were his prey,</br>And, like another Bruys, he lost another fleet.

Thus, long ago,</br>When Britain warded off a blow,</br>(Her cannons seldom mute)</br>Some sycophant his song would suit,</br>Or flatt'ring lyre,</br>To charm the court of France, and kindle warlike ire.</br>At last victorious Nelson came,</br>Rais'd o'er his foes a matchless name.</br>The brave enthusiast from his martial stores</br>Enlarg'd the naval battle's bounds,</br>And spread abroad triumphant sounds,</br>By prompt decisive skill, and feats unknown before.</br>Nelson abroad may gain the prize;</br>At home we share the crown.</br>He blew a mortal to the skies,</br>We sink a demon down.</br>
